dublinCore.dc:title: 113 S2663 IS: Partner with Korea Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Isakson (for himself, Mr. Blunt, and Mr. Begich) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To provide high-skilled visas for nationals of the Republic of Korea, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Partner with Korea Act.

section.header: Reciprocal visas for nationals of South Korea

subsection.text: Section 101(a)(15)(E) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101(a)(15)(E)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (ii), by striking or at the end;
in clause (iii), by adding or at the end; and
by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: solely to perform services in a specialty occupation in the United States if the alien is a national of the Republic of Korea and with respect to whom the Secretary of Labor determines and certifies to the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of State that the intending employer has filed with the Secretary of Labor an attestation under section 212(t)(1);

subsection.text: Section 212(t) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 1182(t)), as added by section 402(b)(2) of the United States-Chile Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act (Public Law 108–77; 117 Stat. 941), is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking or section 101(a)(15)(E)(iii) each place it appears and inserting or clause (iii) or (iv) of section 101(a)(15)(E); and
in clauses (i)(II), (ii)(II), and (iii)(II) of paragraph (3)(C), by striking or section 101(a)(15)(E)(iii) each place it appears.

subsection.text: Section 214(g) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 1184(g)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: The Secretary of State may not approve a number of initial applications submitted for aliens described in section 101(a)(15)(E)(iv) that is more than the applicable numerical limitation set out in this paragraph.
The applicable numerical limitation referred to in subparagraph (A) is 15,000 for each fiscal year.
The applicable numerical limitation referred to in subparagraph (A) shall only apply to principal aliens and not to the spouses or children of such aliens.

subsection.text: Section 214(i)(1) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 1184(i)(1)) is amended by striking section 101(a)(15)(E)(iii), and inserting clauses (iii) and (iv) of section 101(a)(15)(E),.
